direct_answer.text: We start off knowing some basic formulas related to geometry and specifically circles. These include: Area equals pi times radius squared ($A=\pi*r^{2}$); Circumference equals two times Pi times Radius ($\text{C}=2*\pi *r$). As such you may solve problems like this one using either approach - finding each individual circular area first before proceeding onto calculations involving differences amongst them due to varying sizes...and ultimately providing us wththe desired solution! Here goes: To get started right away lets note our known variables herein provided : $$r_{1}=4,\quad r_{2}=6,\quad & \text {radius } \\r_{3}=7&;\\a_{1}=\pi*{r}_{1}^{2},\quad & \text {area around smaller}\\, &\text{inside circle}\\a_{2}=\pi*{r}_{2}^{2},&\quad& \text{middle }\,\, &\text{around circle}&<\\a_{3}=\pi*{r}_{3}^{2}& &text{larger outside};$$ Now according y title above i.e., 'Difference Between Largest And Small

We know the areas of each shaded shape using formulas for circles. Area X equals one fourth times pi times radius squared minus four so $$Area_{X} = \tfrac{1}{4}\pi\cdot 4^2 - 4\pi=4\pi$$ likewise $$\text {area}_{Y}= \dfrac{1}{4}\pi\cdot 6^2-\dfrac{3}{2}\pi=\dfrac{17}{2}\pi.$$ And finally $$\text {area}_{Z}=\dfrac{1}{4}\pi\cdot 7^2 - \left(\dfrac{3}{2}\pi+\pi\right)=\dfrac{17}{2}\pi.$$ Thus since our biggest value here would come directly above Y while our lowest comes along Z it makes sense that the answers differences equal $$Y-Z =\frac{17}{2}\pi -\left(\frac{17}{2}\pi -4\pi\right)=4\pi .$$ Hence the desired differences yields exactly $$4\pi .$$ Note also another way to solve was just simply look at figure!       = π(7)²
      = π(49)
